thread.title: Rover pups take bite out of Phillipsburg in girls cross country shutout
thread.title_full: Rover pups take bite out of Phillipsburg in girls cross country shutout

title: Rover pups take bite out of Phillipsburg in girls cross country shutout
text:
Complete Box Score » 
Lauren Maddison and Skyler Danley made the most of their first Easton - Phillipsburg rivalry event at Saturday morning’s girls cross country dual meet between the two fiercest of foes at the Phillipsburg Athletic Complex. 
The Rover freshmen looked like experienced, assured upper-class athletes as they finished second and third overall, respectively, in 20 minutes, 6 seconds and 20:16, to pace Easton to a 15-50 win over the Stateliners. 15-50 is a shutout in cross country parlance. 
“It’s really exciting to be a part of this,” Maddison said. 
Danley, meanwhile, beamed with delight. 
“We have never run in front of this many people, not even close,” she said. “Usually it’s just our parents. I have never seen so many people at a meet.” 
If Maddison and Danley keep running they way they did Saturday, they may have to get used to attracting crowds. The Rovers (10-0) put on a dazzling display, led by senior Diana Hammerstone in first place at 20:02 and taking the top seven spots. 
“I have been doing this a long time and I don't remember an Easton team that is this talented and this deep,” Phillipsburg coach Joe Grady said. “It was impressive to watch. Obviously I wish we were on the other side of it, but I was still very much impressed.” 
So was Easton coach Bobbi Jo Powell, especially with Maddison, who rise has been meteoric. 
“Lauren wasn’t even in our top group at all until about two weeks ago,” she said. “She is moving up every race.” 
Maddison and Danley hoped for success Saturday but were still surprised but what they accomplished. 
“I was just hoping to be in the top 10,” Danley said. 
Maddison agreed. 
“I didn’t think we’d be second and third like this,” she said. 
Grady, whose top finisher was senior Lexee Willey in eighth in 21:33, couldn’t say enough about the Rovers. 
“Easton is a remarkable team, and they should be commended for a tremendous effort today,” he said. 
Perhaps more cross country athletes should adopt the “Maddison Diet” if they want to run like the Easton freshman did Saturday. 
“Nornally I get bad cramps during a race,” she said. “But today I really ate well before the race. I had a banana, a graham bar, grapes, and water.” 
The winning formula for Danley may have been the PAC course itself, a rolling test with a variety of terrain. 
“I love running on hills,” she said. “It’s fun to run on the hills.” 
Especially when they are outrunning Stateliners. 
“It’s a friendly rivalry,” Maddison said. “But it’s good to have.” 
And to make the most of when you get the chance, as Maddison and Danley did Saturday. 
Brad Wilson may be reached at bwilson@lehighvalleylive.com . Follow him on Twitter @bradwsports . Find Lehigh Valley high school sports on Facebook .
